title: Unary_negation
markdown:
# Unary negation (-)

The **unary negation (`-`)** operator precedes its operand and negates it.

## [Try it](#try%5Fit)

## [Syntax](#syntax)

```
-x

```

## [Description](#description)

The `-` operator is overloaded for two types of operands: number and [BigInt](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global%5FObjects/BigInt). It first [coerces the operand to a numeric value](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Data%5Fstructures#numeric%5Fcoercion) and tests the type of it. It performs BigInt negation if the operand becomes a BigInt; otherwise, it performs number negation.

## [Examples](#examples)

### [Negating numbers](#negating%5Fnumbers)

```
const x = 3;
const y = -x;
// y is -3; x is 3

```

### [Negating non-numbers](#negating%5Fnon-numbers)

The unary negation operator can convert a non-number into a number.

```
const x = "4";
const y = -x;

// y is -4

```

BigInts can be negated using the unary negation operator.

```
const x = 4n;
const y = -x;

// y is -4n

```

## [Specifications](#specifications)

| Specification                                                                                                                                                     |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [ECMAScript Language Specification  \# sec-unary-minus-operator](https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/ecmascript-language-expressions.html#sec-unary-minus-operator) |

## [Browser compatibility](#browser%5Fcompatibility)

BCD tables only load in the browser
